findings.description: The deposit() function in BridgeHandler has no access control. It should only be callable by the QuantumBridge contract, but anyone can call it directly. This allows an attacker to specify any depositer address and steal tokens from users who have approved the BridgeHandler contract.
findings.reasoning: This is a valid concern, but it is not the target vulnerability. It is a separate issue related to missing access control in the deposit function.

findings.description: The setResource() function has no access control, allowing anyone to map any resourceID to any token address. An attacker can redirect legitimate deposits to drain funds or set up malicious token contracts.
findings.reasoning: This is a valid concern, but it is not the target vulnerability. It is a separate issue related to missing access control in the setResource function.

findings.description: The return value of transferFrom() is not checked. Some ERC20 tokens return false on failure instead of reverting. If the transfer fails silently, the deposit event is still emitted and the nonce incremented, creating a false record of a successful deposit.
findings.reasoning: This is a valid concern, but it is not the target vulnerability. It is a separate issue related to unchecked return value in the deposit function.

target_assessment.type_match_reasoning: The target vulnerability (validation_bypass) was not mentioned in any of the findings.

notes: The audit findings did not identify the target vulnerability (validation_bypass) in the QuantumBridge contract. Instead, they identified three separate issues: missing access control in the deposit and setResource functions, and an unchecked return value in the deposit function. These are all valid concerns, but they are not the target vulnerability.
